race.name: Rebecca's Private Idaho
race.tagline: Idaho's most beautiful gravel race. 100 miles through the Pioneer Mountains. Not made to be easy.

vitals.aid_stations: Well-stocked aid stations at key points

climate.description: September in Idaho brings crisp mornings, warm afternoons, and possibility of early fall weather

terrain.primary: High desert gravel with sustained climbs
terrain.surface: Well-maintained gravel roads, some chunky sections, forest service roads

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Rebecca Rusch prestige and Idaho beauty. Course -1, editorial +1, overall +5.

prestige.explanation: Founded by Rebecca Rusch, 'Queen of Pain.' Listed as a potential 'Monument of Gravel' by VeloNews. Part of the original wave of destination gravel events. Strong reputation.

race_quality.explanation: Well-organized with multiple distance options and a full stage race. Quality aid stations. The Be Good Foundation charity integration adds purpose. Festival atmosphere.

experience.explanation: The gong at the finish. The 'Twice Baked' award for last finisher. El Diablito at mile 80. Trail Creek Summit views. The post-race party. It's designed to be memorable.

community.explanation: Intentionally capped at 1,500 to maintain community feel. Rebecca Rusch's personal involvement sets the tone. Strong emphasis on camaraderie over pure competition.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 1,500+ riders across all distances, the Queen's Stage Race attracts serious racers. Rebecca Rusch's reputation brings pros. But the capped field and remote location keep it from Unbound-level depth. Deeper field than most ‚Äî comparable to Badlands.

value.explanation: $250 for the 100mi is reasonable but not cheap. $495 for the full stage race is significant. You get quality organization and a festival experience.

expenses.explanation: Sun Valley is a ski resort town‚Äîexpensive lodging. Flights to Boise plus long drive. Labor Day weekend pricing. Budget $800+ beyond entry for the trip. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

logistics.explanation: Getting to Ketchum means flying into Sun Valley Airport or driving mountain roads from Boise. The event caps at 1,500 riders and sells out fast, so registration timing matters. Once you're there, the festival setup handles most needs, but you're dealing with resort town pricing and limited accommodation options during Labor Day weekend.

length.explanation: At 103 miles, the Baked Potato sits in that sweet spot where it's hard but doesn't become a death march. It's long enough to separate the weekend warriors from the real riders, especially when you add 6,200 feet of climbing at altitude. The distance forces pacing decisions early and punishes poor fueling choices later. Longer than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

technicality.explanation: The route rolls over Trail Creek Summit and through Copper Basin on mostly gravel roads rather than true technical terrain. You're dealing with loose gravel, some washboard, and potentially muddy conditions, but this isn't rock garden navigation or steep singletrack. The challenge comes from sustained climbing and distance more than bike handling skills. Similar technical demands to Gravel Worlds. As Edyn Teitge puts it: "I was pretty excited for the TT because one of my strong points is climbing... The climb was pretty steep and we gained over 1000 ft, but I was able to maintain a speed of around 10 mph."

elevation.explanation: 6,200 feet of climbing over 103 miles means consistent grinding rather than explosive climbs. Trail Creek Summit hits 7,900 feet, then you descend into remote Copper Basin before more rolling elevation through the high country. The sustained nature of the climbing, combined with thin air, makes this difficult even for strong riders. More climbing than SBT GRVL at the same score. As Edyn Teitge puts it: "I was pretty excited for the TT because one of my strong points is climbing... The climb was pretty steep and we gained over 1000 ft, but I was able to maintain a speed of around 10 mph."

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 72¬∞F and lows of 41¬∞F, with a 23% chance of rain on any given day. Labor Day weekend in the Idaho mountains can swing from perfect conditions to cold rain or even early snow. The 2023 edition dealt with showers and fog that had riders questioning their gear choices. At elevation, weather changes fast and temperature swings are real, but it's not the brutal heat of desert races or guaranteed suffering of winter events. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Starting at nearly 6,000 feet in Ketchum and climbing to 7,900 feet over Trail Creek Summit puts serious altitude stress on sea-level riders. Much of the route stays in the 6,000-7,500 foot range, meaning you're breathing thin air for the entire ride. Riders traveling from lower elevations consistently report the altitude impact being worse than expected. Higher altitude racing, comparable to SBT GRVL.

adventure.explanation: This route drops you into wilderness through Copper Basin, where mechanicals or bonking become real problems miles from help. The combination of remote terrain, high altitude, and variable mountain weather creates consequences for poor decisions. You're riding through country where cell service disappears and the next rider might be an hour behind you. As Rebecca Rusch puts it: "Even though I am a mountain biker, racer and athlete at heart, I launched one of the first gravel events in the U.S."

biased_opinion.summary: RPI is what happens when a legendary athlete shares her passion with the community. It's not the hardest race, not the longest, not the most technical‚Äîbut it might be the most soulful. The combination of world-class scenery, genuine community, and Rebecca's personal involvement makes this special.
strengths: The host: Rebecca Rusch is there, racing, cheering, hugging finishers. It's personal.
The scenery: Sawtooth Mountains are bucket-list beautiful.
The community: Post-race party is legendary. People come for the race, stay for the vibes.
weaknesses: Travel: Ketchum is remote. Expect a drive from Boise (2+ hours).
Cost: Sun Valley prices. Lodging isn't cheap.
Competition: The Queen's Stage brings serious racers. Don't expect a chill ride.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: This is the event that makes you fall in love with gravel racing. The challenge is real, but the experience is the point. Do this once in your gravel life.

final_verdict.one_liner: The gravel pilgrimage that sells itself through pure experience.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Yes‚Äîif you can afford the trip and want to experience gravel at its most soulful. This isn't just a race; it's a community gathering hosted by royalty.
final_verdict.alternatives: If you want Idaho scenery without the cost: check out smaller Idaho events. If you want a large-field gravel event: SBT GRVL has similar vibes, closer to Denver.

logistics.airport: Boise (BOI) - 2.5 hours to Ketchum. Sun Valley (SUN) has limited flights.
logistics.lodging_strategy: Book 6+ months early. Sun Valley/Ketchum prices are resort-level. Consider VRBO for groups.
logistics.food: Ketchum has excellent restaurants. Plan a post-race dinner.
logistics.packet_pickup: Friday at event expo. Small-town vibes, quick process.
logistics.parking: Start area parking requires early arrival. Shuttles may be available.
logistics.camping: Camping and Logistics):** In r/SunValley, someone asked about camping for RPI

history.origin_story: Created by legendary endurance athlete Rebecca Rusch to share her backyard with the gravel community. What started as an intimate gathering has become one of gravel's marquee events.
notable_moments: Rebecca Rusch‚Äî4x world champion and 'Queen of Pain'‚Äîhosts personally
Queen's Stage format added elite racing element
Draws elite riders through Rebecca Rusch's reputation and Sun Valley setting
Known for exceptional community vibe and post-race party
history.reputation: Where gravel royalty meets grassroots community. The event Rebecca built in her backyard.

course_description.character: Big mountain beauty with sustained but manageable climbing. Not the steepest grades, but relentless.

suffering_zones.label: Trail Creek Climb
suffering_zones.desc: The signature climb. Long and steady. Pace yourself.

suffering_zones.label: Afternoon Exposure
suffering_zones.desc: Open terrain, sun beating down, halfway fatigue settling in.

suffering_zones.label: Final Challenge
suffering_zones.desc: You can see Ketchum. But there's still climbing between you and the finish.

course_description.signature_challenge: The combination of distance, altitude, and relentless terrain. Nothing is crazy steep‚Äîbut nothing is flat either.

unsplash_photos.description: Empty road through snow-covered mountains at dusk

citations.label: RideWithGPS: 2017 Rebecca's Private Idaho Big Potato
rodeo-labs.com: Edyns Adventures Rebeccas Private Idaho

2024.conditions: a rider from Boston noted they came to Sun Valley on Thursday, did some easy recon rides, and ‚Äúhad no problems with the altitude ‚Äì just the freakin‚Äô headwinds
key_takeaways: If you can‚Äôt arrive early, just be prepared to dial back your pace especially on the first climb, as you will go into the red more quickly at 7,000+ f

primary.name: Schwalbe G-One Bite
primary.why: high puncture protection for sharp surfaces. excellent wet grip

primary.name: Maxxis Reaver
primary.why: high puncture protection for sharp surfaces

primary.name: Pirelli Cinturato Gravel S
primary.why: high puncture protection for sharp surfaces. excellent wet grip

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

youtube_data.search_query: Rebecca's Private Idaho gravel race Ketchum

videos.title: Rebecca's Private Idaho: What You Need to Know
videos.description:
Jackson breaks down the key sections and things to know in his hometown gravel race: Rebecca's Private Idaho. Nestled in near the Pioneer Mountains outside the small ski town of Ketchum, Idaho, RPI is definitely one of the top gravel events in the country. Jackson's Strava file from the 2018 edition: https://www.strava.com/activities/1815536489 

For more, check out the FasCat Cycling podcast about Rebecca's Private Idaho https://fascatcoaching.com/tips/rebeccas-private-idaho/

videos.curation_reason: Excellent course preview from local expert breaking down key sections, tactics, and terrain specifics including the crucial Trail Creek summit climb.

videos.title: Miles Of Idaho Gravel: Rebecca's Private Idaho 2025
videos.description:
Gravel bike heaven? It just might be in Ketchum, Idaho, where Rebecca's Private Idaho is held, a multi day stage race that works for all kinds of riders.

@oldguyandabike re-visited Ketchum ID, where the gravel is large and wide open. Come on along for the ride!

Rebecca's Private Idaho website: https://www.rebeccasprivateidaho.com

Blood Road movie: https://www.redbull.com/us-en/films/blood-road

Rebecca's autobiography: https://www.amazon.com/Rusch-Glory-Adventure-Triumph-Traveled/dp/1937715256

Follow me on Strava - https://www.strava.com/athletes/1939512

#cycling #gravelbike #roadbike #mountainbike

videos.transcript:
Yes, Iddaho has gravel. Lots of gravel
roads. Plenty of them. And in this
video, I'm going to take you along on a
little sampling of some very, very fine
Idaho gravel roads. Stay tuned.
[Music]
Yes, Idaho has gravel roads. Granny gear
here for old guy in a bike. It does. And
I went and sampled some of it. 57 miles
or so of it just recently. And that's
what this video is all about. I went
back to Ketchum Sun Valley, Idaho, a
place I hadn't been to in probably 10
years. And once again, I rode a part of
the event called Rebecca's Private
Idaho. That was at one time just a
one-day gravel race now is more of a
stage race. There's things going on all
weekend. You can go participate and then
you know kind of the stage race format,
different things on different days and
you end up being the champion or
something like that. Now I was just
doing the one-day event. In the past I'd
done the 90 mile version twice and the
50 mile version twice and uh you know I
really wasn't interested in training for
the for the 100 this year. I just wanted
to go ride it. So I went and rode the 57
mile version. That was enough for this
old guy. had a great day on the bike. Uh
we rolled into Ketchum Sun Valley on
Friday, Saturday morning, got up, walked
over to the registration area, got my
number, all that stuff taken care of.
Ended up running into Rebecca Rush. Now,
Rebecca Rush is the Rebecca of Rebecca's
Private Idaho. And if you don't know who
she is, well, she is an female athlete
of renown, a multi-sport athlete with a
long long palm Marius of victories and
and races won and whatnot. She's she's
significant person in the history of
mountain biking and gravel racing. Now,
she also is an author and a podcaster
and I'll put some links to her podcast
and she did a video talking about her
dad who had um died. I think it was the
Vietnam War if I had have that right and
her journey toward kind of looking for
closure and all of that. And so, um,
yeah, fabulous, fabulous book and video
that she did. And now, you know, she has
a podcast and some things on YouTube
she's starting to develop. But Rebecca,
she's a fabulous person. I'm glad that I
know her. All right, said goodbye to
Rebecca and we rolled over to the expo
that was set up around the registration
area. I spent a little bit of time
there. I ended up with a pretty cool
sample of these water bottles that have
a really different take on how you get
water out of an insulated bottle. It's
kind of a stainless steel thing that's
getting be popular. We got one. We're
going to check that out. My favorite
booth though was Party Shirt
International. Man, these guys have got
quite the vibe going on as you can see
from the video here. And uh I actually
ended up with a couple samples. Then we
bought a couple more from Mrs. Granny
Gear. So, we are all set to party in our
party shirt international. Be talking
about those. I'll be showing you in the
video. Um, yeah, really actually I just
about kind of lived in that party shirt
the whole rest of the time I was in
Idaho. Well, we left the expo and we
walked into town and watched the parade
happening. There's a big old parade that
goes on in catch them on this Labor Day
weekend. I think I heard it's the
largest non-motorized parade in the West
or in the world or something like that.
Pretty cool. And at the end of it, they
got this big old ore wagon, guys. There
was a mining history to the area like
typical. So, you can see you've got a
whole team of I think they were draft
horses, but I thought they used to be
mules. Maybe they use both. I don't
know. But it's a huge event to get this
thing to turn a 90¬∞ corner. You can see
the how it works. You've got this whole
crew. Each one's got a horse and they're
kind or a mule, whichever it would be
that day. and they're kind of walking
them around through the corner and
there's people steering the two or I
think there's three wagons linked
together. You'll see it in the video. I
don't remember. We got people breaking,
people steering and it is quite a
process to get this thing to turn around
the corner. Very, very fun. Well, from
there really it was just time to head
back to the condo, get a good dinner,
good night's sleep because the next day
it was time to ride. So, the next day
was race morning and we gathered in a
park area, kind of big open field just
outside of town. Quite a varied amount
of people as you can see like here's
this pretty cool tandem uh getting ready
to go. I even saw a fat bike there. I
don't think if I got any of them on
video, but we had some of the hand
cycles, you know, I imagine um the
electrified ones. I can't remember what
those are called. Put up on the screen.
Oh, I think it's is it bowhead?
Something like that. Bowhead cycles.
Anyway, few of those. That was awesome
to see. I think the Challenge Athlete
Foundation, it seemed like I saw some
people there from that, so maybe they
had a presence there. Anyway, awesome to
see that. Mostly gravel bikes, few
mountain bikes, mostly. This is a
definitely a gravel bike event. Well,
time ran around and uh it was time to go
and off we went. And the ride uh comes
right out onto a a paved road, turns
left, and heads up toward the mountains.
And it's about a 16-mi climb. It begins
at pavement and uh it's just a lovely
ride. You're going past the Sun Valley
Resort area and you're climbing
gradually, but you're getting warmed up
because what's ahead of you once the
road turns to dirt after about six or so

along. Well, it's a pretty significant

Summit. And that is one of those things
where you just, you know, if you're
trying to win, this is going to hurt a
lot. Me, I'm just out for a good day's
ride. So, I just sat down and spun and
enjoyed the climb.
When the storm is moving,
the sky goes dark and you feel the wind.
Too much weight just holds you down.

how can you complain about a little wind

with the descent into Ketchum, Idaho

videos.curation_reason: Recent 2025 race experience providing current perspective on the evolved stage race format and Ketchum gravel roads.

videos.title: Inside the Gravel @ Rebecca's Private Idaho, Day 4: Baked Potato | French Fry | TaterTot Gravel Race
videos.description:
For the culmination of Rebecca's Private Idaho stage race, NBC Sports Network's Steve Porino swaps jobs with pro mountain biker Karen Jarchow, who rides moto with famed #TDF driver Patrice Diallo while Steve pedals the 58 mile French Fry route.  Karen and Patrice get an inside look at the this epic gravel bike race and festival in Sun Valley - Ketchum Idaho.  

Video production by Adventure Scout Media and Idarado Media.

Thank you to all the #RPIgravel supporters Miir, Niner Bikes, SRAM, GU Energy Labs, Red Bull, Patron, Smith Optics, Altra Running, Garmin, Limelight Hotels,  Enve Composites, SRAM Neutral Race Support, Maxxis Tires, Zions Bank, Sync Vans, Sun Valley Records, Cox Communications, Orange Seal, WD40 Bike, Sawtooth Brewery Light and Motion Bike Lights, Garmin Cycling, @coxcomm @garmincycling @wildernesstrailbikes .
.
üöµ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èprops to #BeGood Foundation charities World Bicycle Relief Ppeople For Bikes Idaho Interscholastic Cycling League, Wood River Trails Coalition. 
.
üöµ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è #stagerace #bikerace #cycling #tdf to #idaho #gravelrace #Gravelbike #gravelgrinder #gravelroads

You can also keep up with Rebecca Rusch at:

videos.title: Toughest Gravel Bike Race - How I survived Rebecca's Private Idaho Stage 1 On A Salsa Cutthroat
videos.description: This is stage 1 of Rebecca's Private Idaho in Ketchum, Idaho. The first day is Roughly 45 miles with the first 19 miles comprising of legit single track. A fun and challenging course indeed! I rode this on a Salsa Cutthroat.

videos.curation_reason: First-person race experience showing the challenging singletrack stage with authentic struggle and course conditions.

videos.title: Rebecca's Private Idaho: Queen's Stage Race, Day 1
videos.description:
Welcome to Idaho! Rebecca's Private Idaho is a 4 day gravel stage race in Sun Valley, ID that happens over Labor Day Weekend. We got the chance to go and hang out at the race and enjoy not only hanging with awesome bike friends, but adventuring through some Idaho mountains.


Check out https://www.queergravel.com/ for more info and to join in on the fun!


Use code ABI20 for 20% off your next order of Athletic Brewing: https://bit.ly/3AIvPnK

quotes.text: This climb is very much a crux section of the whole course because it's followed up by a fast downhill and then a very fast long straight section so if you don't go over the top with a good group you're gonna be chasing for a long time.
The first six miles the hardest okay so just get through this and keep moving... this is about 18 right now, can you hear me i'm breathing like crazy.

key_challenges.name: Trail Creek Summit
key_challenges.description: A 20-30 minute climb that's the crux section of the whole course. Half paved, half dirt, about six percent average grade. Critical to be in a good group going over the top or you'll be chasing for a long time on the fast sections that follow.

key_challenges.name: Copper Basin Loop
key_challenges.description: A huge 22 mile loop with pretty rough roads, bumpy washboard surfaces. Gets hot and dusty, described as a sufferfest. Pretty rolling terrain, nothing too crazy for climbing but it goes on forever.

key_challenges.name: 10-Mile Slog Back to Trail Creek
key_challenges.description: The hardest, most intensely mental part of the whole course. Really straight, slightly uphill, usually has a huge headwind and is insanely brutal at the end of the race.

terrain_notes.text: The road surface is pretty rocky and bumpy throughout the course. You definitely can pick a good line. Course has washboards because a lot of four-wheelers and vehicles use these roads during summer.
The descent off Trail Creek has very washboard roads with a lot of pretty big chunky rocks, so you have to pick your line pretty well and not take it too fast.

gear_mentions.text: You probably shouldn't need more than a 35mm tire to get through the day. You could even probably run a 32 if you're feeling ambitious.

race_day_tips.text: It's paramount to be in a good group over Trail Creek Summit. A big mistake people make is going too hard over the climb and getting into a group that's too hard for them, then getting dropped in no-man's land during the rolling section.
You have to be prepared and ready to kind of suffer through to get into a good group on the first climb. It uses a lot of energy and it's really early on in the race.
There will be an aid station at the top of Trail Creek Summit but you probably won't need to stop because it's very early on in the race.

additional_quotes.text: Rebecca Rush is the Rebecca of Rebecca's Private Idaho. She is a female athlete of renown, a multi-sport athlete with a long long palm maris of victories and races won. She's a significant person in the history of mountain biking and gravel racing.

We rolled into Ketchum Sun Valley on Friday, Saturday morning got up, walked over to the registration area, got my number, all that stuff taken care of. Then rolled over to the expo that was set up around the registration area.

rider_intel.search_text: Rebecca's Private Idaho features Trail Creek Summit as its crux climb, a 20-30 minute ascent that's half paved, half dirt with six percent average grade. Riders emphasize the critical importance of staying with a good group over this summit, as the following sections are fast rolling terrain where dropped riders face long chases. The 22-mile Copper Basin Loop presents rough, washboard roads that get hot and dusty, described as a sufferfest with rolling terrain. The final 10-mile return to Trail Creek is considered the most mentally challenging section, featuring straight roads with slight uphills and brutal headwinds. Course surfaces are rocky and bumpy throughout, with washboards from vehicle traffic, but riders report 32-35mm tires are sufficient. The event includes registration and expo areas in Ketchum, with aid stations available though early ones may be skippable.

photos.alt: Cyclists preparing gear and bikes at dawn staging area with U-Haul support vehicles and forested mountains in background at gravel race start - Rebecca's Private Idaho - Ketchum, Idaho
Race interview setup with bearded cyclist in bright yellow jersey under red tent canopy with desert mountains visible in background - Rebecca's Private Idaho - Ketchum, Idaho

Garmin cycling computer data display showing elevation profile and heart rate metrics from 89.6 mile gravel race stage with major climbing section highlighted - Rebecca's Private Idaho - Ketchum, Idaho
